report_title: Municipal Building Construction in the US
executive_summary: The industry consists of various noncommercial markets, mainly healthcare, educational, religious, governmental and recreational facilities. Government funding accounts for almost all educational and public building construction, while the private sector funds most healthcare and religious constructions. Local and state government investment has inched down; at the same time, as states paid out millions of unemployment insurance claims during the pandemic, tax revenue and government investment shifted away from construction projects. Skyrocketing interest rates, coupled with a declining value of nonresidential construction, have also made it less profitable to start new construction projects. Revenue has dropped at an expected CAGR of 0.2% to $243.0 billion through the current period, despite an expected 3.3% jump in 2024 alone as government investment has rebounded.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Health and Public Safety Construction Carry Growth
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Contractors received support from surging demand for healthcare construction in 2020 following COVID-19. Revenue swelled, outstripping dwindling contracts from other markets. Input prices increased significantly after supply chain disruptions, pressuring profit down to 2.6%. Contractors will benefit from expected lower interest rates and more contract availability as economic conditions improve. Revenue will climb at 1.0% CAGR to $254.8B in 2029. While nonessential building construction slowed during the pandemic, demand for healthcare and public safety facilities skyrocketed, carrying industry growth.

Low interest rates spurred industrial building construction before the pandemic. Following inflation, the Fed raised interest rates multiple times through 2022-2024, discouraging new projects. Building material prices also grew expensive. The Russian invasion added uncertainty. Crude oil volatility increased construction costs. It's become difficult to hire skilled labor, so companies use more subcontracted labor to reduce payroll costs. Subcontractors provide flexibility to hire temporary local workforces.

It's become more difficult for contractors to hire skilled labor – most companies have faced rising wage costs. Instead, contractors have opted to use subcontracted labor, increasing purchase costs. Subcontractors are paid only until a project is completed, reducing a contractor's annual payroll. Subcontractors give companies flexibility to compete across the US and hire temporary local workforces. Smaller companies form development consortiums to bid for larger contracts together.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: World Sporting Events Come to the United States
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The US will host major sporting events like Grand Prix races, the 2028 LA Olympics and 2026 FIFA World Cup. This will require massive infrastructure updates, creating opportunities and labor needs. However, much revenue is for work outside the industry like excavation. Contractors able to operate across markets will avoid cyclicality and reap the most success.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: The Private Market Supports Municipal Construction Activity
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Growth in the private sector will result in more public-private partnerships, even as borrowing remains costly. This often involves upfront private investment followed by government spending, planned for new baseball stadiums. Schools will continue using federal grants like the Supporting America's School Infrastructure Grant Program which received new 2023 funds.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Rebounding Construction Markets Will Support Growth
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Contractors will rally as private nonresidential construction value recovers and individuals/businesses opt for larger projects. More contracts will be available for bidding. Interest rates will normalize, making projects less expensive to fund. Input prices will recede as supply chains recover, leading to stable profit growth, though Russian sanctions present steel volatility.

industry_definition: This industry comprises contractors that are responsible for the complete construction (i.e. new work, additions, alterations and repairs) of institutional buildings, such as schools, hospitals, churches, civic centers and prisons. The industry also includes operators that perform construction management on institutional building projects. Types of operators include general contractors, design builders, engineer-constructors, joint-venture contractors and turnkey contractors.
key_trends: Competition among contractors is driven by reputation. Established relationships and positive word of mouth can aid operators in acquiring new contracts.
Large-scale and long-term contracts have closed off the market for smaller operators. Many contractors have organized into development consortiums which bid together for larger contracts.
Subcontractors give operators greater flexibility. Larger construction companies can hire temporary subcontractors instead of hiring wage labor to cut costs.
Borrowing costs have skyrocketed. High interest rates have pushed businesses away from renovations and new projects. Interest rates are expected to fall in the coming years.
Successful companies will provide services across multiple construction industries. Even so, specialization can be a strong way to improve a company's reputation to win better contracts.

Foreign ownership and participation have increased. Turner, for example, is a subsidiary of German construction giant, Hochtief; Skanska (Swedish), Suez (French) and Bovis (British) are other examples of foreign companies operating in the United States.

The industry faces heavy regulation. Operators must take care to adhere to OSHA standards and building codes or risk severe litigation. Regulators have placed a greater emphasis on sustainability in construction practices. Contractors can receive tax incentives for obtaining LEED certifications.
Subcontracting grows in popularity, especially as the construction sector combats labor shortages. Subcontracting provides contractors with greater flexibility than full-time workers.
Rising purchase costs have dampened profit growth. Rising interest rates have also made it costly to begin new construction projects.
The spread of operators across the country generally follows population trends. The Southeast region, for example, has abundant, low-cost labor and land.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Education market benefits from increased public-sector spending
Aging population and COVID-19 drive demand for healthcare buildings
Recreation and amusement construction suffers during pandemic
Social unrest and pandemic drive public safety spending
Religious building construction relies on private spending

products_and_services.product_description: General Contracting Remains the Most Sought-After Service
Remodeling provides a less-expensive alternative for clients

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Increased private investment in nonresidential construction leads to an increase in the construction of municipal buildings.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast has the largest percentage of US population
The West region's large, affluent population
Mid-Atlantic region: affluent economy provides room for growth

regulations_points.regulation_description: Currently, a broad range of codes govern activity in this industry, ranging from general building to state and local zoning regulations. The International Code Council develops and endorses building codes.

Enforcement of a building's compliance with codes occurs at several points before and during the construction. This includes project architects and consulting engineers, who check the design against current codes and standards and submit the designs to local jurisdictions to obtain the permit for construction.

regulations_points.regulation_title: The Federal Office of Safety and Health Administration (OSHA)
regulations_points.regulation_description: Health and safety regulations require that protective clothing and helmets be worn on-site and that safe conditions are provided for workers, such as scaffolding, harnesses and ventilation. The Federal Office of Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) enforces standards for the construction industry, which are contained in Title 29 of the Code of Federal Regulations.
(CFR) Part 1926. State and local building authorities assess and enforce this code. Adherence to the OSHA regulations will limit exposure to workplace accident litigation and high insurance premiums.

regulations_points.regulation_title: Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design (LEED)
regulations_points.regulation_description: LEED certification provides independent, third-party certification that a building was designed and built using sustainable construction methods. LEED certification requirements are developed through consensus-based committees and administered by the US Green Building Council (USGBC).

barriers_points.barrier_description: The life cycle stage of the industry is a factor for increased barriers to entry.

basis_points.basis_title: Competition among contractors is driven by reputation.
basis_points.basis_description: Established relationships and positive word of mouth can aid operators in acquiring new contracts.

basis_points.basis_title: Large-scale and long-term contracts have closed off the market for smaller operators.
basis_points.basis_description: Many contractors have organized into development consortiums which bid together for larger contracts.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Nonemployers make up the largest portion of establishments
concentration_points.concentration_description: The majority of businesses within the industry employ fewer than five employees and very few enterprises hire more than 100 employees. Many within the industry as sole proprietors or partnerships, acting as subcontractors and hired on a job-by-job basis.

concentration_points.concentration_title: The use of subcontractors has grown over the past five years
concentration_points.concentration_description: Operators prefer to pay higher fees for subcontractors to mitigate the risk of paying wages while work remains scarce.
Only the largest operators have the scope and capital to operate on a national or global scale. Major companies are largely shielded from the competition between small contractors.

concentration_points.concentration_title: The narrow scope of this industry also decreases larger players' market share
concentration_points.concentration_description: The majority of construction companies operate across general nonresidential construction markets instead of specializing in municipal building construction specifically.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Bricks, mortar, timber, steel and other expendable tools are used in the construction process. Steel, in particular, had a severe price shock in 2021, leading to significantly elevated purchase costs.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: LICENSE AND INSURANCE COSTS REMAIN A HURDLE FOR CONTRACTORS
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: While licensing costs and regulations vary by state, these costs present a significant upfront cost. Companies also provide insurance for employees; given the manual nature of the work, insurance premiums tend to be high. Contractors also incur significant vehicle costs since travel between worksites is required.

While profit increased prior to 2021 as companies made use of more efficient construction methods and subcontractors, the following years paint a different picture. Current levels account for rising purchasing costs, namely the prices of steel and oil. The cost of labor and subcontractors has also shot up as the construction sector struggles with a labor shortage.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Skilled labor is essential to success. Workers are needed every step of the way from planning to operating heavy machinery.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Rising interest rates have made it more expensive to fund new projects and source necessary inputs. In particular, loans and mortgages have become more expensive. The price of steel also skyrocketed in 2021, coinciding with rising rates and supply chain contractions following the pandemic. As steel prices fall, the profitability of projects will rise.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Reliance on Federal Funding Limits Fluctuations
volatility_points.volatility_description: The industry typically endures less volatility amid economic downturn compared with the overall construction sector due to its reliance on federal and state funding. For example, the federal government implemented various stimulus packages that assisted the industry, helping to mitigate volatility during the pandemic.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: ENVIRONMENTALLY FRIENDLY BUILDING DEVELOPMENTS ATTRACT NEW DEVELOPERS
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Development toward sustainable materials coupled with client preference for environmentally friendly designs provides an area of growth in the industry. Contractors that follow green guidelines set by the Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design rating system will also be eligible for tax incentives.

Contractors that have added computer-aided design and drones to map out worksites and design workflows have reaped greater efficiency and precision than others. This type of equipment is often cost-prohibitive to many of the smaller operators and nonemployers in the industry. Large companies, like Turner, have a significant advantage.

FAQs.question: How does your company hedge against economic downturn?
FAQs.answer: Demand for municipal construction will typically follow the general business cycle. Amid an economic downturn, countercyclical budgetary action will support demand for municipal construction projects. However, revenue will mostly follow trends in state and local government budgets since they are the main clients.

FAQs.question: How does your company protect itself from market risk?
FAQs.answer: Specialized companies may have a superior reputation, increasing sales. Nondiversified companies may experience greater revenue volatility, hurting future earnings. Overall, companies that cater to a diverse range of downstream projects will be less volatile and less exposed to market risk.

FAQs.question: Is your company located in close proximity to buying and selling markets?
FAQs.answer: Companies located in proximity to upstream suppliers will exhibit lower purchase costs and greater profitability. Companies located not in proximity to end markets will have higher transportation costs, hindering profitability. The overall structure of the industry necessitates that operations be fragmented geographically since it is uncompetitive to offer services outside a specific range.

FAQs.question: Has your company contended with volatile input prices?
FAQs.answer: Companies that enter into long-term supply agreements with suppliers can protect themselves from future input price increases, protecting themselves from upside risk.

FAQs.question: How is your company leveraging the latest technologies?
FAQs.answer: Companies using the latest technologies will exhibit higher operational efficiencies and wider profit. Drones have become a viable commercial technology for municipal building construction contractors via the Federal Aviation Administration's legalization of using commercial drones. Overall, using them to scope out job sites, heat maps and 3D models are some examples of using this labor-saving technology.

FAQs.question: Has your company been able to reduce wage costs via technology?
FAQs.answer: Companies with the latest technologies will be more price-competitive because of labor cost savings. However, wage costs can be most easily reduced via the subcontracting of nonessential employees as well as only keeping specialized employees on the books full-time.

FAQs.question: Is your company prepared to meet shifting environmental standards?
FAQs.answer: Companies with an environmentally friendly reputation may be preferred by the public, increasing sales volumes. Noncompliant companies will be subject to fines and penalties, reducing profitability. With potential shifts to environmental regulations could cause municipal building construction contractors to exhibit an increase in operating costs. More specifically, since this is a publicly funded industry, public authorities may not be able to accept bids from non-compliant contractors.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all occupational health and safety requirements are upheld?
FAQs.answer: Companies with a proven reputation for safety may be favored in the contract tender process. Noncompliant companies will exhibit insurance premium cost increases, reducing profit.

FAQs.question: How does your company's profit margin compare to those of your competitors?
FAQs.answer: Companies using the latest technologies will have higher operational efficiencies and wider profit. Companies that engage in long-term supply management will have lower purchase costs and greater profitability. Companies must serve to differentiate themselves from their competition via a strong reputation for quality and under-budget projects. Since contractors are publicly-funded, the least cost is of critical importance in order to win contracts.

FAQs.question: Does your company experience any difficulty financing current operations?
FAQs.answer: Most construction projects are financed by credit or debt and rising interest rates will inhibit borrowing to fund current operations. Countercyclical budget action by the federal government can increase funding in times of economic downturn. It is important to note that revenue from projects is not realized until after completion, requiring significant cash reserves and steady cashflow to see companies through periods of depressed demand.

FAQs.question: How often do you subcontract industry activities? Do you regularly enlist the help of independent operators and consultants?
FAQs.answer: It is essential that contractors ensure proper resource allocation and rectify issues that may arise during any given stage of a project. Via the subcontracting of less essential tasks, municipal building construction contractors are able to keep cashflow free for any unexpected budget items.

FAQs.question: More so in public rather than private tenders, how do you ensure the lowest price for a bid to be awarded a contract? How are you able to offer low prices?
FAQs.answer: Much of the work generated by this industry is awarded by public tender, so operators must have a proven capacity to compete by offering the lowest price. Typically since government institutions are financially constrained, offers of the lowest price will generally be more favorable in this industry rather than in adjacent construction industries.

FAQs.question: Do you have a good relationship with your subcontractors? How do you assess which subcontractors you do business with?
FAQs.answer: Contractors' heavy reliance on subcontracted labor makes it essential for them to maintain good relationships with a pool of skilled subcontractors.

FAQs.question: Is your company prepared to adapt to rising long-term interest rates? Does your company track interest rates closely?
FAQs.answer: As the yield and interest rates rise, municipal building contractors in both the public and private sectors will exhibit increases in borrowing costs, limiting demand for new projects.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor population trends? How does the growth of the US population affect demand for your services?
FAQs.answer: A larger US population creates a greater need for municipal buildings like schools, hospitals and other public facilities. This translates into greater revenue for the industry, as more buildings must be built to accommodate the growing population.

FAQs.question: Does your company rely overwhelmingly on public funds?
Does your company do a lot of work with local and state governments?
FAQs.answer: As local and state government investment increases, so does spending on municipal building construction.
